- develop own forms of expression

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Principles of Chinese Calligraphy
courses.description: This course is offered for beginners in Chinese calligraphy. It describes the basic concepts and techniques of Chinese calligraphy, the selection and use of materials and tools, and teaches students the regular, clerical and seal scripts. Students will be prepared for more advanced courses of various scripts.

After completing the course, students will be able to:

- manage general knowledge and usage of the four treasures of Chinese studio;
- recognize the characteristics of different formats of Chinese calligraphy; and

- apply what they learn in the class to the creation of elementary Chinese calligraphy in clerical and regular scripts

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Principles of Chinese Painting
courses.description: This course introduces the materials and tools, techniques in brushwork, ink tone variations, and colouring to beginning students of Chinese painting. Related skills such as mounting, writing of inscriptions, imprinting of seals will also be explored. Students will practise traditional paintings of pine trees, rocks, bamboo, and human figures, etc., in preparation for in-depth studies in landscape, figure or bird-and-flower paintings.

After completing the course, students will be able to:

- understand the content and basic concept of Chinese painting;
- manage basic techniques in brushwork, tone variation and coloring of Chinese painting; and

- apply what they learn in the class to the creation of elementary Chinese painting

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Fundamentals of 3-Dimensional Forming
courses.description: This course provides students with basic concepts and skills in three-dimensional forming through various material processes, both in traditional handicraft and digital 3D forming environment. Emphasis will be placed on three major aspects: 1) the perception of form and space; 2) materials and construction; and 3) 3D form as artistic expression. The course will also help students to get familiar with studio operations that would equip them for further sculptural practice.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Observing Form & Space

Understanding the nature as well as the structure of diverse natural and man-made forms and spaces.

2. Transformation of Form & Space

Explore various ways of form-space-transformation that lead to ideas/concepts of 3D artistic expression.

3. From 2D Plane to 3D Form

Pattern cutting as a means of analyzing, de-constructing and re-constructing a 3D form.

4. 3D Construction - from Handicraft to Digital Forming and vice-versa

Investigate wide range of possibilities to further develop a hand-built sculptural form within a digital environment. Usage of 3D scanner and printer will be introduced and practiced. The final piece should be a combination of hand-crafted and digital forming.

5. The Container & the Contained

A tailor-made container / box will be constructed to house the sculptural form developed in the previous stages. Relevant images as well as different materials / textures will be explored and eventually applied onto the container / box to further reference the conceptual development of the sculptural form. Usage of appropriate tools and machinery will be introduced and practiced.

courses.description:
(UGEA1310 is double-coded with FAAS1600.)

In light of artifacts whether excavated or collected as well as historical texts, this course provides an overview of Chinese art over 5000 years. Through studying the art and culture of the pre-historic era and the Bronze Age, and the development of painting, calligraphy, religious sculpture, architecture, jade, gold, silver, and ceramics throughout the centuries, students will understand the special characteristics and historical development of Chinese art and culture over the centuries. Artistic exchange between China and its neighbouring countries will be given special attention. Tutorial sessions involve practical workshop or the study of actual art objects at the Art Museum.

Students will gain a basic understanding that besides aesthetics and forms, artwork represents the culture, philosophy, religion, technology, literature, and history when it was produced and collected. Critical art historical concepts including but limited to style, mass production, iconography, patronage, narrative, connoisseurship, and forgery, will be used to analyze masterpieces to hone students’ object-based research skills.

4. Style

5. Mass production

6. Iconography

7. Patronage

8. Narrative

9. Fine art and craft

10. Connoisseurship

11. Forgery

12. Literati art

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Life and Arts in Pre-Modern China
courses.description:
(UGED2316 is double-coded with FAAS2100.)

In the traditional discourse of Chinese painting, it was believed that an artist should “外師造化，中得心源” (outwardly learn from the Nature and inwardly trace the source of their own heart). Unfortunately, with the enormous temporal and geographical difference, both the Nature and the “heart-source” of the ancient masters, as well as their techniques in articulating the two, appear to be unapproachable to us living in the modern age. Likewise, the field’s ambiguous meta-language full of expressions like “氣韻生動” (infusing ch’i to show life movement) or “意趣” (subtle charm resulted from spontaneity) can also be a hurdle to uninitiated students.

Distant it might seem, art, after all, is inspired by real life. This course seeks to explore the material basis of the Nature artistically heightened by the ancient artists directed by their “heart-source”. We would try to explore the abstract philosophical ideas and aesthetic ideals by looking at something physical and concrete: by visiting specific scenic sites, we would be able to compare the landscape with the paintings they inspired and have more idea on how the visual vocabulary and grammar of Chinese painting “translates” the real world; and by viewing the objects, or even experience some of the activities central to the artists’ cultural life, students would also have a more substantial understanding on the “heart-source” of these painters.

This course would use the Songjiang and Wu Schools of painting as case studies. A field trip will be organized and students will be walked through the areas of Shanghai, Suzhou and Hangzhou where the Ming Dynasty painters were active in. Through the well-preserved tangible heritage of the region, students could have a better feeling of the intangible ideational world of the ancient masters and their artistic pursuits. The endeavours of the local communities in preserving these invaluable treasures will also be reviewed.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. 能有意識地以連結自身生活經驗的方式觀看藝術，發掘藝術與自身的關聯

2. 比較真實的山川地貌與其在不同畫家筆下迥異的呈現方式，從而觀照中國繪畫程式化語言的發展

3. 分析明代藝術文化之盛與江南物質生活之豐的關係

4. 思考古人的生活與藝術在現代社會的意義並了解現時有哪些保護文化遺產的努力

After completing the course, students should be able to:

1. Appreciate artworks in relation to their personal experience and discover the relevance of art to them.

2. Relate topographical features to the styles of individual artists, which would later become pictorial conventions

3. Attribute the flourishing of art and culture of the Ming period to the prosperity of the Jiangnan region.

4. Evaluate the meaning of ancient life and art to modern people and understand what have been done to keep the cultural heritage alive.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *甲、山水之間「師造化」** **——** **旅遊、觀察自然與藝術創作**

- 「不行萬里路，不讀萬卷書，欲作畫祖，其可得乎？」：古今山水畫的歷史及美學

- 自然的真實與藝術的真實：啓發藝術的山水風光及傳統技法下的山水風光

* *乙、「心源」之源** **——** **明代文人的生活與其思想及藝術**

- 中晚明社會：繁榮市場經濟及對隱逸淡泊的追求並存

- 明代文人文房之雅 （對書畫、篆刻、碑帖、瓷器、紫砂、玉雕等收藏的審美）

- 明代文人生活之雅 （昆曲、園林、絲綢、遊山玩水）

* *丙、古代藝術的當代呈現與存在意義**

- 歷史與文化傳統的當代價值

- 文化傳承的多種手法 （博物館、文化旅遊、手藝傳承及當代藝術創作）

* *A.** **Travel, Nature and Art**

* *-** The history and aesthetics of Chinese landscape painting

- The “translation” of Nature with the language of ink and brush

* *B.** **Life, Ideas and Art of the Ming Literati**

- Mid to late Ming dynasty: prosperous market economy and the pursuit of hermitage

- Elegance in the studio: Ming dynasty connoisseurship on calligraphy, painting, seal carving, rubbings, porcelain, zisha wares, jade carvings

- Elegance in everyday life: kunqu, garden architecture, silk, travelling

* *C. Representation of ancient art in the modern age and its meaning**

- Relevance of history and culture to the present

- The multiple means to preserve cultural heritage (museum, cultural tourism, apprenticeship, modern art)

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Arts of Ancient China:Neolithic Through Bronze Age
courses.description: Using artifacts recovered from archaeological excavations, this course will explore the artistic achievements of early China. Students will be introduced to the painted and black pottery and the ritual and ornamental jades from the Neolithic period; oracle bone script, ritual bronze vessels, bronze weapons and musical instruments, painted lacquers, and ritual and ornamental jades of the Bronze Age; as well as the beginnings of contact with nomadic cultures, and pictorial representation in bronze, silk, and clay. Students will emerge with a multifaceted picture of the cultural and artistic legacy of early China, ready for in-depth studies in the arts of the period.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: History of Early Chinese Ceramics
courses.description: This course examines the development and artistic characteristics of Chinese ceramics from the Neolithic period (ca. 5000-2000 BCE）to the Song dynasty. Representative wares such as early painted and black pottery, funerary figurines, stonewares, and high-fired porcelains from major kilns will be discussed. This course also explores the relationship between the ceramics and the social culture of different periods through in-depth analysis of excavated materials from archaeological sites such as tombs, kilns and pagodas. Excavation of ancient Chinese ceramics in Hong Kong will also be included in the survey, with the possibility of field visits to local archaeological sites.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Visual and Material Culture of the Ming Dynasty
courses.description:
(UGEC2391 is double-coded with FAAS2106.)
This course discusses the changes of visual and material cultures of the Ming dynasty through studying objects, images and texts. Topics including ceramics, lacquerwares, gold and precious stones, textiles, prints and other art and artefacts made for people from all walks of life will be covered. Through introducing representative images and objects and different trends of social development of the Ming period, such as religious fervor, sumptuous consumption, and erotic culture, the course aims at exploring how the emergence of classic images and artefacts are linked to the political, economic, religious, technological and aesthetic development of a time.
courses.course_syllabus:
The following topics will be covered in the course:

(1) Visual Culture & Material Culture

Introduction to the concepts of visual culture and material culture and their application to the study of art and culture of the Ming dynasty in the past decades.

(2) Ming Society and Ming Cities

Discussing the social and geographical structure of the Ming empire, especially the relationship between the emperor and his court in the capital (Nanjing and Beijing), Ming princes in their princedoms, officials, businessmen and literati in Jiangnan and other major provinces.

(3) Material I: Ceramics and Everyday Utensils

Technological advancements in ceramic production in the imperial porcelain factory at Jingdezhen, Jiangxi and the consumption of different types of ceramics in Ming society.

(4) Material II: Gold, Precious Stones and Body Accessories

The import of precious stones in the Ming dynasty and the discovery of personal accessories made of gold and precious stones from tombs in conformity to/ in violation of sumptuous laws.

(5) Material III: Textiles and Costumes

Technological advancements in dyeing and weaving and the clothing fashion in late Ming Jiangnan.

(6) Material IV: Lacquers and Ornaments

The cultural and technological exchange in lacquer production between China, Japan and Ryukyu, and the increasing emphasis on creating visual effect in object production.

(7) Material V: Prints and Books Culture

Technological advancements in printing in the late Ming period and the spread of visual knowledge across different social strata through catalogues of material objects (such as patterned papers and ink cakes) and illustrated books.

(8) Case Studies: Representative Images across Different Media

The use of the same images (such as *qin-qi-shu-hua*, i.e. playing *qin-*zither, chess, reading and appreciating paintings) in different material objects and their changing meaning through the Ming dynasty.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Religious Art of China
courses.description:
(UGED2306 is double-coded with FAAS2110.)

This course aims at exploring the relationship between Chinese art and religion from the Shang period onwards. Students will be introduced to religious paintings, buildings, sculptures, clothes and ritual objects. Through studying important archaeological and extant religious artifacts and recent research on Chinese religious beliefs, students are expected to understand the characteristics and significance of Chinese religious arts. Religious ideas behind different forms of art will also be discussed.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 圖像、目的、意義：早期青銅禮器

‧禮器上的紋飾與當時的宗教祭祀有何關係？

‧怎樣詮釋商周青銅器上的動物紋飾的宗教目的和意義才算合理？

2. 器物群組與思想：先秦至漢墓葬形制及隨葬品

‧分析一件宗教藝術品與詮釋一組墓葬出土文物的宗教性有何差異？

‧如何通過對比先秦至漢墓葬形制及隨葬品組合，得知時人對死後世界的看法？

3. 物料、目的、意義：早期墓葬中的玉和石

‧物料如何取得其在特定文化中的宗教含義？

‧先秦至漢代的人如何使用玉石建構他們理想的死後世界？

4. 圖像群組與功能：從西王母到仙佛祥瑞圖像

‧**何謂祥瑞？祥瑞圖在中國傳統社會有何功能？**

‧**設置在漢至六朝的宗教建築和器物上的仙佛圖像，如何令其使用者達至吉祥的目的？**

5. 神靈與地理：山嶽崇拜與早期山水圖像

‧山在中國古代的宇宙觀中有何重要性？

‧先秦以來對山嶽的崇拜如何衍生出各種以山水為題材的藝術作品？

6. 佛教壁畫、文本與地方文化：敦煌和新彊壁畫中的佛傳故事、本生故事、因緣故事

‧何謂佛傳故事、本生故事、因緣故事？

‧這些宗教主題在敦煌和新彊兩地不同的文化影響下，如何在壁畫上呈現各自的藝術特色和信仰重點？

7. 佛教壁畫、文本與儀式：經變畫

‧何謂經變畫？

‧敦煌的經變畫如何體現地方信徒對經文的理解、地方工藝傳統，以及經變畫的功能？

8. 佛教造像、文本與地方文化：佛教造像與觀音變相

‧佛教的經典如何解釋典型佛教造像的特徵？

‧以觀音菩薩為例，其在印度佛教和佛經中的形像，如何結合中國地方文化而改變？

9. 佛教思想與民間想像：六道輪迴、地獄的繪畫與石刻

‧佛經中如何描述六道與地獄？

‧ 中國民間對死後世界的思像，如何影響佛教有關六道輪迴和地獄圖像在中國的發展？

10. 宇宙圖式：道教的道、仙道、丹道的圖像表現

‧宇宙（Cosmos）在道教的思想中有何重要性？

‧宋代以來，道教如何運用圖像來表達其仙道和丹道的思想？

11. 道教神仙與地方信仰：永樂宮與呂祖信仰

‧道教如何建構其神仙系譜並將之以圖像呈現？甚麼因素促使神仙的形像改變？

‧ 從元代山西永樂宮到現今香港的道堂，呂祖（呂洞賓）的形像經歷了微妙的變化。

12. 神靈與地理：武當山與真武大帝

‧ 神靈如何與特定地點建立關係？皇室與信眾在當中扮演怎樣的角色？

13. 宇宙圖式：密教與藏傳佛教的曼荼羅

‧密教與藏傳佛教如何透過平面和立體的曼荼羅表達對宇宙的理解？

‧佛教、道教的宇宙圖式在概念和功能上有何差異？

courses.title: Introduction to Asian Art: The Art and Archaeology of West, South, Southeast, and Inner Asia
courses.description:
(UGED2315 is double-coded with FAAS2113.)

The survey introduces the art and material culture of pre-20th century Asia with particular attention paid to trans-regional and cross-cultural interactions. Select artistic traditions in West (mainly, Iran), South (India, Sri Lanka, and the Himalayas), Southeast (Indonesia, Burma, Thai, Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam), and Inner (Afghanistan, Tajikistan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan, and Mongolia) will be examined against their philosophical, religious, socio-political, economic, aesthetic, and technological backgrounds. Major themes include (1) the rise of civilizations, (2) developments of various artistic forms and media, (3) tombs and funerary paraphernalia, (4) the spread of Buddhism, Hinduism, Islamism, and other worldviews across the region, and (5) Indianization and Sinicization.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: History of Western Comics
courses.description:
(UGEC2317 is double-coded with FAAS2116.)

This course traces the history of comics and graphic novels in Western Europe and North America. Beginning with an introduction presenting the main characteristics of this medium, this course will trace its development, from the beginnings of storytelling with images in Antiquity to the latest innovations. Even though they have retained their own characteristics over the last two centuries, Western European and North American comics have also developed in close proximity. Following the development of the press and book industry, as well as other media like cinema, comics and graphic novels have a rich history that can only be understood in their cultural context. This course is designed to allow students to understand how this medium has shaped and been shaped by many aspects of the history and cultures of these places.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Introduction: What is Sequential Art**

How to identify the characteristics of the medium know as ‘comics’

* Why the concept of ‘sequential art’ is a more comprehensive way to define the medium of ‘comics’
* How academic authors understand the notion of sequential art

* *Historical Precedents of Sequential Storytelling**

How comics in their modern form emerged from other art forms from the past

* Origins of sequential story telling from Antiquity to the early 19th century

* *European Precursors**

How European precursors redefined sequential storytelling

* Europe until the late 19th century: the main source of original comics
* first full-fledged practitioner of this medium, Rodolphe Töpffer (1840-1846)
* influence of other media on comics (in particular new printing technology and cinema)

* *North American Early Comics**

How full-fledged comics emerged in North America

* Emigration of many artists to North America in the late 19th century
* The comics strip in commercial context of the mass media (newspapers)

* *European Early Comics**

How comics became mainstream in Western Europe, from the beginning of the 20th century to the inter-war period.

* Thriving publication industry that grew through specialization
* Specialized for children and young persons
* A few exceptions of more adult-oriented comics

* *North American Golden Age**

How comics grew to become a thriving global industry

* The new superpower status of the United States gave to American comics a global reach
* Mickey Mouse, Popeye the sailor become world-wide influences
* The period sees the creation of an entire culture of superheroes symbolizing American global dominance in the realm of popular culture

* *European Golden Age**

Less globally influential at first, European comics also become globally significant

* New European comics under the influence of North American culture
* Other European comics developed as original creations that also enjoyed a global readership
* Growth of a comics industry geared towards an adult readershop

* *North American Renaissance: Underground Comix**

How the North American counterculture redefined the medium of comics

* End of the censorship on comics imposed in the 1950s
* Expansion of the possibilities and public of the medium
* Influence on the present

* *European Renaissance: the 1970s and beyond**

How both mainstream and counterculture began to expand the field of comics

* More gradually than in North America, comics became a medium for an adult readership
* Creation of many independent comics publishers and magazines
* Growing literary ambitions of comics creators
* Comics become an accepted field of academic research

* *Reshaping the Medium**

How the new directions initiated after the 1970s became a global explorations of new forms and contents

* Comics become a highly literate field of artistic creation: the advent of the graphic novel
* The influence of academic research on the medium
* The influence of new technologies on comics creation

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Global Currents in Contemporary Art
courses.description:
(UGEC2371 is double-coded with FAAS2118.)
Contemporary art is diverse and expansive, and its timeline, topics, and aesthetic strategies, are continually redefined. This course offers an introduction into political and aesthetic issues addressed in global contemporary art, particularly since 1989 which marked the fall of the Iron Curtain and the first primordial “global” exhibition at Centre Pompidou. It will provide a variety of perspectives to discuss visions of the future presented by artists from diverse cultural backgrounds, who engage with such global issues as migration, borders, postcolonial conflicts, gender perspectives, environmental crisis, biodiversity, and digital capitalism. It will provide students with foundational knowledge on the emergence, developments, and challenges of global contemporary art discourses, as well as their contesting relationship with artistic autonomy and the society. We will examine a range of topics and methods employed by influential artists and thinkers in various geographies. This will provide a toolkit for understanding and curating contemporary art. To put critical thinking into practice, we will integrate exercises such as screenings and discussions, group projects, and exhibition proposals. Beyond art historical perspectives, we will also delve into questions regarding humans’ relationship with each other and the nonhumans, which are fundamental for understanding global currents and crisis addressed in contemporary art.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. Identify major global art trends and key influential artworks from Europe, the Americas, Asia-Pacific, and Africa since 1989.
2. Examine the origins of and developments of the concept of global contemporary art in relation to postcolonial and posthuman discourses.
3. Recognize, differentiate, and explain the transcultural and transregional topics and issues that contemporary artists and curators engage in their works in the larger geopolitical contexts.
4. Build informed opinions on the quality and relevance of the arts since 1989, paying attention to their relations with global and local political and historical events.
5. Develop skills in speaking in public and organize research materials.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. **Introduction: Autonomy**

In this introduction session, we will cover some fundamental ideas and debates of global contemporary art, including the issues of autonomy, timeline, and social engagements, referencing theories and curatorial practices since 1989. Drawing from selected international museum collections, we will unpack a variety of institutional and geopolitical contexts that contributed to the formation of global contemporary art.

1. **Feminism**

This session will be devoted to feminist criticisms in art history, specifically the dialogues between women’s art and feminist movements between the 1970s and post 2000s. We will draw from several group exhibitions in Asia and the Americas post-1989 to discuss the issues of essentialism and representation in feminist Art histories.

1. **Queerness**

This session introduces various artistic approaches in deconstructing queer identities and bodies, mainly through selected case studies in digital and performance art. Students will be encouraged to compare these with discourses introduced during the last session, and discuss ways of decentering and expanding conventional feminist discourses.

1. **Migration**

In this session, we will examine the concepts of mapping and displacements in the context of specific political and environmental crises. To do so, selections of contemporary gallery films by minority or immigrant artists will be screened, followed by a discussion.

1. **Transculturality and Border Art**

Drawing from transcultural studies and border studies, we will examine several media and performance art works as well as curatorial approaches that cope with cultural conflicts and hybridity. Selected case studies include *Magiciens de la terre* in Paris in 1989, the Whitney Biennale in New York, Asian Biennale in Taichung, and documenta Kassel.

1. **Colonialism**

This session focuses on visual art creations that address natural resource extraction and indigenous rights issues. It will start with an introduction to primitivism in modern art, then move on to reactions to Imperialism in works by South-East Asian and African artists as new nation states and identities emerge.

1. **Indigenous Art and Postcolonialism**

We will talk about First Nations land justice and reconciliation in this session. An institutional history of indigenous art will be covered first, then selected contemporary practices and their cultural representations under specific government policies. Particular attention will be given to discourses in Canada, Australia, and the New Zealand.

1. **Environmentalism**

This session introduces discourses of eco-art and the Anthropocene. We will also draw from political ecology to discuss artistic approaches to environmental justice. Issues of community engagement and green washing will be attended.

1. **Bio Art**

This session provides an overview on the history of bio art, its application in industries, the public reception, and the ethical issues.

1. **Digital Capitalism**

In this session, we will look at artistic reflections on surveillance and digital capitalism through concrete examples. We will screen selected essay films that engages with data discrimination, surveillance infrastructure, and deepfake, followed by a discussion.

1. **Asian Diaspora**

In this session, we will discuss the definitions of diaspora and the Sinophone through visual arts. We will look at artists outside of Mainland China who engage with “Chinese” identities differently. Works by such artists as Ian Cheng, Patty Chang, Musquiqui Chihying, and Lee Wen will be discussed.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Western Art I: from the 15th to the Late 19th Century
courses.description: This course aims to give a broad overview of Western art from the 15th to the late 19th century. The Renasissance is universally regarded as a fundamental period in the history of Western Art. Subsequent period styles, such as Mannerism, Baroque, Neo-Classicism, Romanticism and Realism are either development from the art principles of the Renaissance or reactions against the rules and bounds developed during this important period. Special attention will be given to the major artworks of each movement as well as the historical events which have influenced the evolution of Western art.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- know the general timeframe of the developments of Western art from the early Renaissance to the late 19th century;
- situate an artwork (sculpture, painting and architecture) within a time period: for example, recognize whether a painting is a High Renaissance or a work of the Romantic period; and

- understand the historical background of each period.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Late Gothic and Early Renaissance in Northern Europe

- Early Renaissance in Italy and the rest of Europe

- High Renaissance and Mannerism

- Baroque: Caravaggism in Europe

- Baroque and Classicism

- Continental Rococo and English art

- Neoclassicism

- Romanticism and its period

- Realism and its period

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Mineral-pigment Painting
courses.description:
In the history of Chinese art, particularly in the realm of Chinese mural art, the use of mineral pigments as the primary painting medium is now known as mineral-pigment painting. Mineral-pigment painting once had a glorious past, and the Dunhuang murals are still hailed as classic works of art.
This course hopes to inherit and protect the precious cultural heritage of mineral-pigment painting, and to expand the use of the aesthetic qualities of mineral pigments, combined with individual creative concepts and expression techniques, to become a unique modern painting medium.
As an ancient painting material, mineral pigment has both the heavy-body covering characteristics of oil and the transparency of watercolor, and now is being ‘ rediscovered’ by many contemporary artists ; not only the course will cover traditional method, but will also explore various possibilities in contemporary expression of mineral pigment painting.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1. Classical Chinese Mural Copying:**

Through the copying of ancient Chinese murals, students will understand the history of murals and master the materials and techniques used in traditional mural painting.

* *2. Sketching and Creation:**

Cultivate students' interest and ability to translate observable world into visual language of mineral-pigment , and then use their imagination to create personal styles and convey their own ideas.

* *3. Color Composition and Configuration:**

Mineral pigments are insoluble in any solvent and cannot be mixed together; therefore, color expression is achieved through the use of configuration techniques and the composition of color layers.

* *4. Lecture on the Production Steps of Mineral-Pigment Painting Supports:**

Understand and master the preparation of glue, alum paper, mounting boards, texture creation, and the making of clam powder grounds.

* *5. Understanding the Types, Characteristics, and Techniques of Mineral-Pigment Painting Colors:**

Mineral pigments, earth pigments, enamel colors, and plant watercolors, etc.

* *6. Metal Foil Application Techniques:**

Applying, burning, cutting, and sprinkling foil, etc.

* *7. Practical Steps of Mineral-Pigment Painting .**

* *8. Analysis and Appreciation of Classic Works of Mineral-Pigment Painting from Ancient and Modern Times, both Domestic and International.**

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Becoming a Comics Director
courses.description:
In addition to artistic skills such as drawing, composition and the understanding of color, storytelling is one of the essentials of comics art. These skills in isolation are however not sufficient to create original comics and this art form can only exist through the proper arrangement of visual elements and image-text interactions. This course aims to provide students with the necessary understanding to further develop their understanding of visual and narrative communication through the creation of a story in the form of comics. In order to enhance students’ capacity to create such an interaction of narrative and images, workshops in the assisted creation of stories will be provided alongside the development of the student’s own visual research. Students will also be encouraged to find their own visual language and graphic style.
Comic writing is a demanding profession that requires a number of specialized skills. This course will offer training and tutorials in the skills most appropriate to comics creation such as character design, script writing and the kind of sensitive observation that leads to intelligent creativity. Other specialized skills, such as insights into the marketing of comics and management of high-pressure schedules, will also be presented to students; this course will prepare potential comics creators for any future challenge in the profession.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: FAAS1100
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. Understand and master comics drawing tools as well as basic digital technical skills

2. Research a comics project through the creation of a sketch book

3. Understand and master character design

4. Understand and master story telling techniques for comics

5. Understand and master the creation of a story board

6. Present their own projects in the form of presentation and the creation of a comics fans page

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Mixed Media
courses.description: After World War II, art media are no longer confined to specific materials, tools and techniques. Artists tend to think and make art through idea rather than material. This has caused confusion between conceptual art and visual art. This course will teach students the basic concepts of mixed media, and provide students with a framework for artistic creation, when no well-defined boundaries for material and technique can serve as a reference. Focus will be put on the three principles of mixed media, namely, physicality, cultural signification and spirituality.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to understand:

- how to practice contemporary art, such as concept, method and it’s operation in society

- how concept could be elaborated and manifested through material

- how to appreciate idea driven art

- develop individual skill and approach of mixed media; and

- critical thinking in art
courses.course_syllabus:
- The three principal of Mixed Media, namely, Physicality, Cultural Significance and Spirituality.

- Art and society—Relational/ Interventional approach of art

- Develop and adapt individual presentation skill for various ideas

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Art, Archive and Technology
courses.description:
This course examines the intersection of contemporary art practices with archives, data analytics, and technology. It delves into the dialectic relations between history, archive, and art. Furthermore, we will explore immersive narratives as a means to showcase contemporary art practices, using archives to investigate the present and envision the future.
The course begins with an analysis of seminal theoretical texts and case studies in archival art practices. We will then delve into the fundamental concepts of data analytics, exploring how algorithms and big data have transformed our methods of acquiring knowledge. Students will critically assess the approaches and challenges of artists’ archival practices and data analytics tools through theoretical discussions and case studies of various artworks. These discussions will emphasize how artists engage with data or inventories to interpret and think. Students will complete a creative project to synthesize their learning.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1. Introduction: Archival Art Practice in Digital Age**

In this introductory session, we will cover fundamental ideas and debates surrounding archival art practice in contemporary art. How do the digital aspects that challenge traditional archival history reshape our understanding of archival art practice? To what extent can these challenges be leveraged as opportunities for art practice using digitally enhanced tools within Digital Humanities?

This class will also introduce the course structure, reading materials, teaching methods, timetable, and assignments.

* *2. The Archival Impulse and Contemporary Contingencies**

This class will explore the powerful impulse to archive in contemporary culture and its significance in historical knowledge and remembrance. It will also examine the evolving attitudes toward archives in modern and postmodern art, focusing on how artists engage with archival practices and create counter-archives.

* *3. Memory, Forgetting, and Re-presentation in Archival Art**

This class will investigate the role of memory and forgetting in archival art. It will discuss how traces in documents and archives serve as testimony to past events and how artists use these traces to create new narratives. The concept of “détournement” in collage and the practice of collecting will also be explored.

* *4. The Digital Archive and Ephemeral Art**

This class will examine the impact of digital technologies on archival practices, focusing on the transition from physical to digital archives. It will discuss the fluid and dynamic nature of digital archives and their potential for new memory cultures. The class will also explore the ephemeral nature of contemporary archival art and its implications for preservation and memory.

* *5 What is Data Science?**
This class will cover the fundamental concepts of data science and the latest developments in AI for text analysis, particularly in the context of big data. We will also consider the impact of data on archival practices. Additionally, we will discuss the features and limitations of data mining in cultural analytics.

* *6. Data Science Tools**

Explore the tools of data science that relate to archival art and the ethical considerations of using AI tools. Discuss the concept of algorithms in text analysis, focusing on the open-source data mining software, which uses a set of rules or procedures to perform various data analysis tasks. Examine the impact of digital technologies on text analysis and data visualization.

* *7. Workshops on Digital Preservation**

In this class, students will be introduced to the fundamental technologies of virtuality, under the category of Extended Reality (XR) and 3D scanning. We will discuss the unique characteristics of computational media, distinguishing it from other forms of media. And its application on digital preservation.

* *8. Workshops on Virtual Reality**

This workshop will teach students the basic use of software and hardware tools to create virtual immersive narratives. Students will gain practical skills for integrating technology into their artistic practices, enhancing their ability to produce digital art experiences with articulation of concepts and methods from the course.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Digital Imaging Workshop
courses.description: The course is designed to explore the concepts, aesthetics, and techniques of digital imaging from both academic and studio perspectives. Both technical and aesthetic issues will be addressed. Aesthetic issues encompass concept, composition and historical context, whereas technical topics include raster and vector imaging, image manipulation, time-based 2D graphics, animation and other related topics. Digital imaging software and hardware will also be introduced to illustrate the principles and techniques and to produce the projects.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- create still 2D compositions exploring visual elements such as points, lines, forms, colors, and symbols, in a digital environment;
- create 2D compositions and animations with digitally captured images, computer-generated images and found images with a sense of rhythm and structure; and

- present computer-based artwork (image) with appropriate presentation hardware and space, such as projection, screen, monitor, and printing materials.
courses.course_syllabus:
1 Digital imaging: Creating and capturing image digitally, as well as obtaining from other analog mediums

2 Motion graphics: Applying special effects, compositing, and color correction to collected and computer-generated images in order to explore transformation of basic visual elements

3 Animation: Making use of sequence of images in a video format for creating narrative

4Text and Image: Exploring visual communication through graphics, text and digital collage

5 Abstract Animation: Exploring visual rhythm with basic visual elements in animation format

6 Web Art: Understanding approaches of delivering aesthetic experiences via the Internet

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Jades for Life and Death
courses.description: The signature products of the major jade-working centres of the Neolithic period (ca. 5000-2000 BCE), their possible meanings, functions, and implications for cultural exchange as reflected in recent excavations will be the focus of the first half of this course. The subsequent changes in function and meaning, and the development of new forms to accompany these changes, will be examined during the second part of the course, aiming for an understanding of the changing meanings of jade in the ritual, religious, political, and social context of the time. Original works of art from the Art Museum and local collections may be used for instruction when appropriate.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Jade: What is “jade”? - Material properties and working techniques

2. Jades in death: Ritual jades from Neolithic burials in southeast China

3. Jades in death: Ornamental jades from Neolithic burials in southeast China

4. Jades in death: Ritual & ornamental jades from Neolithic burials in north China

5. Jades in death: Archaeological and ritual context in north China

6. Jades for ritual: Neolithic to Bronze Age in north China

7. Jades for ritual: Inheriting from the Neolithic in the Bronze Age

8. Jades for life and death: Lady Fu Hao’s jades at Anyang

9. Jades for life and death: the Western Zhou revolution

10. Jades for life and death: the Eastern Zhou transformation

11. Jades for life after death: burial jades & quest for immortality

12. Jades and life: After the Han Dynasty

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Jingdezhen and Beyond: History of Later Chinese Ceramics
courses.description: As the “Capital of Porcelains”, Jingdezhen has played an important role in the history of later Chinese ceramics. This course will examine the organization, the mode of production and the artistic characteristics of the monochrome and painted porcelains of Jingdezhen, to understand the achievements of the Ming and Qing ceramic industry. Trade ceramics and its influence, as well as ceramic production in Hong Kong will also be discussed with a field visit to a ceramic kiln site at Tai Po.
courses.course_syllabus:
有「瓷都」之稱的江西景德鎮，自元代以來，一直在中國窯場中居領導地位，對晚期中國的瓷器發展，以至世界各地的瓷器生產，均影響深遠。本科透過討論明清御窯廠的組織、運作、各種產品的藝術特色和特徵，探討各時期瓷器的藝術成就和時代意義，並討論景德鎮瓷器的外銷和影響。
專題包括：
景德鎮的製瓷工藝
元蒙皇室與元代瓷器
明初景德鎮官窯的成立
朝廷需求與技術飛躍：明代宮廷瓷器
帝皇品味與宮廷文化：明代官窯瓷器
消費市場的角色：明末清初的民窯瓷器
水下考古的發現：明代瓷器對外貿易
督陶官與帝皇品味：清代宮廷瓷器
官樣制度與宮廷裝潢：清代宮廷瓷器
消費市場的角色：清代外銷瓷
明清地方瓷窯：宜興、石灣、德化
二十世紀景德鎮瓷

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Art of the Elite: Calligraphy from Song to Qing
courses.description: This course traces the development of calligraphy from Song to Qing. Major topics include the Song expressive calligraphic styles, Yuan revivalism, model-calligraphy tradition from Ming to mid-Qing, and stele-calligraphy tradition since mid-Qing. In addition to major calligraphers and their masterworks and styles, this course will also examine the philosophical ideas embodied in calligraphy, thus providing students with a cultural understanding of why calligraphy has been regarded as an art of the elite in China.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Contemporary Art: Artistic Strategies in a Postmodern Era
courses.description: The goal of this course is to explore Western art and theory from approximately 1945 to the mid-1990s. Special attention will be given to the shift from a modernist to a postmodernist culture, and how artists have endeavoured to address a new era characterized by globalization and consumerism. Whenever possible, contemporary Chinese artworks will be explored for the purposes of cross-cultural comparison.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- understand the developments of European and North American art from the end of WWII to the present days and especially the reasons why the traditional divisions in schools and movements that endured well into the 1960s does not make sense any longer;
- understand the motivations of the most influential artists of that period and how their works were both a product of their time and an engine for the development of other kinds of art practices; and

- and be able to interpret the artworks made by contemporary artists by situating them in the cultural context within which they were created.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Media Art: Body, Technology, Time
courses.description: This course presents an overview of significant theories and case studies in media art history, spanning from the Enlightenment to the 21st century. It will introduce discourses and histories in Europe, America, and Asia. Topics and mediums discussed include the camera obscura, early film, intermedia installations, Net art, the digital turn, sound art, media art preservation, performance, and digital theatre. Class activities will include a visit to a local museum or archive, group discussions, and a presentation at the end of the semester. Drawing on key artworks and fundamental theories, it aims to guide students to explore how media-based practices evolved in various social environments responding to the history of technology, and develop research skills for academic writing and curating.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:
1. identify major media art movements from the Enlightenment to the 21st century
2. apply major theories of media art to research essays and curatorial projects
3. history of optical and sound devices
4. identify issues surrounding exhibiting and preserving media art in museums
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1. Introduction to the Time-based Media: History, Mediums, Concepts**
This session explores the early history of time-based media and telecommunication art. There will also be an introduction on the formation of media art history as a discipline.

* *2. The materiality and temporality of film**
Two sessions will be devoted to the history of moving image, the documentation and representation of time in early time-based media, and the development of gallery film.

* *3. Photography**
This session will cope with the history and theory of photography, as well as the impact of the digital turn on the photographic practice.

* *4. Video and interactive media**
This session explores the development from analogue and digital video to multi-media installation. It will also discuss transnational networks of intermedia practice such as Fluxus.

* *5. From performativity to digital theatre**
Two sessions will be devoted to the history of performance art and the liveness discourse, as well as an overview on the genealogy of digital theatre.

* *6. Game art and net art**
This session is devoted to the intersection of game art and video art. We will also discuss case studies of net art.

* *7. Data capitalism**
This session explores the concept of born-digital objects and conservation practices. It will also draw from Hito Steyerl’s creative works and critical writings to discuss data capitalism and problems resulted by data discrimination in the metaverse.

* *8. Posthuman positions**
This session is devoted to environmentalism in creative arts and live art.

* *9. Media art in Asia**
Two sessions will be devoted to the history of video art in China and Japan. A field trip to a local museum will be integrated.
courses.feedback_evaluation: A clear teaching plan will be provided before the course commences. An evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Buddhist Art and Architecture
courses.description:
(UGEC3308 is double-coded with FAAS3110.)

This survey explores the historical development of Buddhist visual and material culture from around 5th century BCE to 20th century CE in Asia from a trans-regional perspective. Major topics include, but are not limited to, (1) worship icons, (2) materiality and ritual protocols, (3) iconography and iconometry, (4) illustrations, manuscripts, and pictorial narratives, (5) relics and other charismatic objects, (6) sacred space and monumental architecture, (7) artistic styles and their development and diffusion, and (8) patronage and socio-political context. The course also introduces the religion of Buddhism viewed uniquely in light of archaeological context.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to:

1. Gain proficiency in analyzing individual works of painting, sculpture, and architecture created by each Buddhist tradition in different part of Asia.
2. Identify regional variances, trans-regional diffusions, inter-regional commonalities, and historical transformations among cultures of the pan-Buddhist world.
3. Fostering familiarity with the philosophical tenets of Buddhism and their historical development.
4. Develop skills in writing academic essays and in delivering public speech.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Introduction; India I: Maurya, Śuṅga**

How is sacrality construed in society?

* The Buddha, bodhisattvas, aniconism, *stūpa*, *jātaka*, *caitya*, *vihāra*

* *India II: Kuṣān, Sātavāhana**

How does society visualize a divinity?

* Gandhāra, Mathurā, Andhra

* *India III: Gupta, Post-Gupta, and Pāla**

How differently is beauty conceived in different societies?

* Sārnāth, Vākāṭaka

* *Central Asia**

How do different communities interact with one another?

* Bamiyan, Khotan, Kucha, Kumtura

* *Sri Lanka & Southeast Asia**

How does one thing in a society mean something else in another?

* Anuradhapura, Polonnaruwa, Borobudur, Bagan

* *Himalayas & Mongolia**

How does a selected few control knowledge in society?

* Tantra, thangka, mandala

* *China I: Eastern Han (25-220 CE) to Jin (265-420)**

What does it take for a society come to terms with a new ideology?

* Soul jars (*hunping* 魂瓶), Kharoṣṭhī, piece-mold casting

* *China II: Northern Wei (386-535)**

How does society alter things according to necessity?

* Dunhuang, Binglingsi, Yungang, Sinicization

* *China III: Eastern/Western Wei vs. Northern Qi/Northern Zhou, Sui**

How does religion work in service of politics?

* Persecution, Latter Days, archaeological hoards

* *China III: Tang, Five Dynasties, Song, Liao & Jin**

How does society preserve values?

* Relics and reliquaries, pagoda, timber-frame building

* *Korea**

How does society deal with a foreign culture?

* Three Kingdoms, Unified Silla, Koryŏ

* *Japan**

How is it like when there are competing beliefs?

* Asuka, Nara, Heian, Kamakura

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Chinese Ceramic Technology: Theory and Practice
courses.description: The aim of this course is to explore the technology of ancient Chinese ceramics through both lectures and workshops. A selection of classic wares from major kilns will be discussed in the lectures. Focuses will be placed on the technique of firing, forming and decorating ceramics and the related kiln technology. Meanwhile students will have opportunities in workshops to apply various ceramic techniques they learn in the lectures to the actual making of ceramics. This course can be taken as either an Art History or a Studio Arts elective course but students are required to declare their choice of attribution in their final year of attendance.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- understand the history and basic technology of representative Chinese ceramics;
- develop skills in writing essay on ceramics; and

- apply their knowledge on Chinese ceramic technology in making ceramics.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Auspicious Metal: the Ritual Bronzes of Ancient China
courses.description: With special emphasis on recent excavations, this course will look at the artistic and technological development of cast-bronze artifacts from around 1600 BCE to the last few centuries BCE, in an attempt to understand China’s unique achievements in relation to other ancient Bronze Age civilizations. Ritual bronze vessels and weapons will be studied as reflections not only of artistic developments, but also of political, social, religious, and economic developments of the time. Original works of art will be used as teaching material when appropriate.

(UGEC3309 is double-coded with FAAS3113.)

This course—an interdisciplinary study of art history, archaeology, anthropology, and religious studies among others—introduces the visual and material culture of the Korean peninsula and its adjacent regions from the Neolithic Age to the early twentieth century CE by surveying major historic monuments and excavated artifacts. Major topics include (1) state formation, (2) tombs and mortuary furnishings, (3) the influx of Buddhism and its successful development, (4) capitals and provinces, (5) elite culture of the court, aristocrats, and the literati, (6) ceramics and lacquerware, and (7) trans-regional interaction, especially, with China and Japan.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Pre-Historic: Neolithic to Bronze Age**

* Stone tools; early settlements; potteries, undecorated & comb-patterned earthenware; petroglyphs; dolmens; narrow-blade bronze daggers, double-knobbed bronze mirrors

* *Proto-Historic: Old Chosŏn** **朝鮮 (trad. 2333-108 BCE)**

* Jizi (Kija) 箕子; *Samguk sagi* 三國史記, *Samguk yusa* 三國遺事; Tan’gun 檀君; Wei Man (Wi Man) 衛滿

* *Puyŏ** **扶餘 (ca. 2nd century BCE-494 CE), Chin** **辰 and Sam-Han** **三韓 (“Three Hans”)**

* State formation; King Tongmyŏng 東明; Dong-, Xituanshan 東-西團山, Mao’ershan 帽爾山, Jilin 吉林; Ma Han 馬韓, Chin Han 辰韓, Pyŏn Han 弁韓

* *Imperial Han** **漢 Commanderies: Lelang** **樂浪 (108 BCE-313 CE)**

* Four Commanderies (*sijun* 四郡) of Western Han Emperor Wu Di 武帝, Lintun 臨屯, Xuantu 玄菟 and Zhenfan真番; Daifang 帶方; chariots, lacquerware; wooden-chambered & brick-built tombs

* *Koguryŏ** **高句麗 (trad. 37 BCE-668 CE)**

* Cholbon 卒本, Kungnaesŏng 國內成, P’yŏngyang 平壤; stone-piled, stone-pyramidal, & stone-chambered tombs, murals; stela, calligraphy

* *Paekche** **百濟 (trad. 18 BCE-660 CE)**

* Wiryesŏng 慰禮城, Ungjin 熊津, Sabi 泗沘; Songsan Ri 宋山里 Cemetery, King Munyŏng Wang’s 武寧王 Mausoleum; Nǔngsan Ri 陵山里 Cemetery

* *Silla** **新羅 (trad. 57 BCE-668 CE) & Kaya** **伽耶**

* Kyŏngju 慶州, *kurgan*, gold, harness, armory, Buddhism; iron

* *Unified Silla (668-935 CE)**

* Monasteries, temples, stone pagodas, reliquaries, statues

* *Parhae (a.k.a. Bohai)** **渤海 (698-926) & Later Three Kingdoms (892-936)**

* Centers vs. provinces, stylistic evolution, iconographic inventions

* *Koryŏ****高麗 (918-1392)**

* Kaegyŏng 開京; celadon; Mongolian style; Buddhist painting & manuscript illustrations

* *Chosŏn** **朝鮮 (1392-1897)**

* Seoul; wooden buildings; “Powdered Celadon” (*punch’ŏng* 粉靑); porcelain; literati culture; genre painting

* *Korean Empire (1897-1910) & The Twentieth Century**

* Japanese Colonialization; DPRK & ROK

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Art and Culture of Japan
courses.description:
(UGEC3319 is double-coded with FAAS3114.)

This course—an interdisciplinary study of art history, archaeology, anthropology, and religious studies—introduces the visual and material culture of the Japanese archipelago from the Prehistoric Age to the twentieth century by surveying major monuments and sites. Major topics include (1) prehistoric potteries, (2) tombs and mortuary furnishings, (3) the influx of Buddhism and its successful development, (4) capitals and provinces, (5) elite culture of the court, aristocrats, and the learned, (6) ceramics and lacquerware, and (7) trans-regional interaction, especially, with China and Korea.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Introduction;** **Jōmon** **縄文** **Period**

* Ecology, geography; demographics, linguistics, ethnicities

* Ainu People

* Jōmon potteries, *entō* 円筒, *dogū* 土偶, Umataka 馬高 Type

* Stone Circles

* *Yayoi** **弥生** **Period:** **New** **Immigrants (*toraijin*** **渡来人****)**

* Yayoi potteries; Toro 登呂 Settlement

* *dōtaku* 銅鐸, *kesa-dasuki* 袈裟襷 (from Sanuki 讃岐)

* bronze mirrors, *kaokumonkyō* 家屋文鏡

* *irimoya* 入母屋 (“hip-and-gable building”)

* *Kofun** **古墳** **Period: State Formation**

* keyhole-shaped tombs (*zenpō kōenfun* 前方後円墳); Daisenryō 大仙陵; Fuji-no-ki 藤ノ木; Takamatsu 高松

* Shintoism; *kami* 神

* *jinja* 神社; *torii* 鳥居, *katsuogi* 鰹木; Izumo 出雲, Ise 伊勢

* Wa 倭, Queen Himiko 卑弥呼 of Yamatai 邪馬壹, Mimana 任那

* *hajiki*土師器; *sueki* 須恵器; *haniwa* 埴輪 (“clay-coil”) potteries

* “Nomadic Conquest Dynasty” hypothesis

* *Asuka** **飛鳥** **Period** **(552-645): Advent of Buddhism**

* Shaka 釈迦, Yakushi 薬師, Amida 阿弥陀

* Soga 蘇我 Clan, Ishibutai 石舞台, Asuka-dera 飛鳥寺

* Tori Busshi 止利仏師, Kuratsukuri 鞍作 Clan

* Prince Shōtoku 聖徳

* Hōryū-ji 法隆寺, Ikaruga-dera 斑鳩寺, Chūgū-ji 中宮寺

* pagoda*, kondō* 金堂, *zushi* 厨子, Tamamushi 玉虫

* Yumedono 夢殿, Guze Kannon 救世観音, Kudara Kannon 百済観音

* *Hakuhō** **白鳳** **Period (645-710): Accomplishment of Buddhism**

* Kōryū-ji 広隆寺

* Lady Tachibana 橘

* Yumechigai Kannon夢違観音

* Yakushi-ji 薬師寺

* *Nara** **奈良** **Period (710-794): Completion of Centralized State**

* Heijō 平城 Capital

* Kōfuku-ji 興福寺

* Tōdai-ji 東大寺, Great Buddha (*daibutsu* 大仏), Hokkedō 法華堂, Kaidan’in 戒壇院, Shōsōin 正倉院

* Tōshōdaiji 唐招提寺, Jianzhen/Ganjin 鑑真

* *Heian** **平安** **Period (794-1185): Rise of Aristocracy**

* Kyōto 京都, Fujiwara 藤原 Clan, Murō-ji 室生寺, Byōdō-in 平等院

* Single-block woodcarving (*ichibokuchō* 一木彫) vs. “combined wood” (*yosegi* 寄木), “alternating-wave style” (*honpashiki* 翻波式), Jōchō 定朝

* Esoteric Buddhism (Mikkyō 密教); *mandara* (*mandala*), “Womb World” (*taizōkai* 胎蔵界) vs. “Diamond World” (*kongōkai* 金剛界)

* Tō-ji 東寺

* *emaki* 絵巻 (“picture scroll”), *Genji* *M**onogatari* 源氏物語

* *fukinuki yatai* 吹抜屋台 (“blown-off roof”), *hikime kagihana*引目鉤鼻 (“line for an eye, hook for a nose”)

* *Kamakura** **鎌倉** **Period (1185-1333): Feudalism and Democratized Buddhism**

* monastic portrait (*chinzō* 頂相); Chōgen 重源

* Unkei 運慶 & Kaikei 快慶

* Tankei 湛慶, Sanjūsangendō 三十三間堂

* Kōben 康弁, Tentōki 天燈鬼 & Ryūtōki竜燈鬼

* Kōshō 康勝, Kūya 空也

* *raigō* 来迎

* *Ippen hijiri**-**e* 一遍聖絵, *Shigisan engi* 信貴山縁起

* *Muromachi** **室町** **Period (1333-1568): Political Crisis and Zen Buddhism**

* Ashikaga 足利 Shougunate

* Kinkaku-ji 金閣寺, Ginkaku-ji 銀閣寺

* Ryōan-ji 龍安寺; dry landscape (*kare-sansui* 枯山水)

* Daitoku-ji 大徳寺

* Zen 禅; Mokuan黙庵, Josetsu 如拙, Shūbun 周文, Sesshū 雪舟, Mincho明兆

* Tosa 土佐 School, Kanō 狩野 School, *fusuma* 襖 panel, *shōhekiga* 障壁画, *yamato-e* 大和絵 vs. *kanga* 漢画

* *Momoyama** **桃山** **Period (1573-1603): Samurai****侍** **as Cultural Elites**

* Oda Nobunaga 織田信長, Toyotomi Hideyoshi 豊臣秀吉

* Himeji 姫路, keep (*tenshukaku* 天守閣)

* Kanō Eitoku 狩野永徳, Hasegawa Tōhaku 長谷川等伯

* Sen no Rikyū 千利休; Shino-yaki 志野焼 & Oribe-yaki 織部焼

* Nanban 南蛮

* *Edo****江戸** **Period (1603-1868): Contact with the West**

* Tōkyō 東京; Tokugawa 徳川 Clan

* Chiyoda- jō千代田城, Katsura桂離Imperial Villa, Tōshō-kū 東照宮

* “drip-in technique” (*tarashikomi*溜込), Tawaraya Sōtatsu 俵屋宗達, Ogata Kōrin 尾形光琳

* Ike no Taiga 池大雅, Yosa Buson 与謝蕪村, Uragami Gyokudō 浦上玉堂, Watanabe Kazan 渡辺 崋山

* *bunjinga* 文人画, *nanga* 南画

* Itō Jakuchū 伊藤若冲; Soga Shōhaku 曾我蕭白

* *ukiyo-e* 浮世絵

* Hishikawa Moronobu 菱川師宣, Kitagawa Utamaro 喜多川歌麿, Tōshūsai Sharaku 東洲斎写楽

* Katsushika Hokusai 葛飾北斎, Utagawa Hiroshige 歌川広重

* *japonisme*

* *sakoku* 鎖国, *ranga* 蘭画, Shiba Kōkan 司馬江漢

* Enku 円空

* *Post-Restoration (1868-1945): Modernization and Imperialism**

* Meiji 明治 Emperor; *giyōfū* 擬洋風 (“pseudo-Western style”) architecture

* *yōga* 洋画 vs. *nihonga* 日本画

* Takahashi Yuichi高橋由一, Asai Chū 浅井忠, Kuroda Seiki 黒田清輝, Kume Keiichirō 久米桂一郎, Hosui Yamamoto 山本芳翠

* Ernest Fenollosa & Okakura Kakuzō 岡倉覚三

* Kanō Hōgai狩野芳崖, Hashimoto Gahō 橋本雅邦, Yokoyama Taikan横山大観, Shimomura Kanzan下村観山, Hishida Shunsō菱田春

* Tomioka Tessai 富岡鉄斎

* Koga Harue古賀春江, Kitawaki Noboru 北脇昇

* *Post-War; Conclusion**

* *mingei* 民芸, Yanagi Muneyoshi 柳宗悦, Bernard Leach, Hamada Shōji 濱田庄司, Munakata Shikō棟方志功, Serizawa Keisuke 芹沢銈介

* Gutai 具体 Group, Mono-ha

* Kawara On河原温, Murakami Takashi 村上隆, Kusama Yayoi 草間彌生

* manga*, *anime*, *otaku*

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: The Art of Chinese Seals
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the artistic characteristics and development of Chinese seals. Content includes the function, forms and related historical issues of ancient seals, and the style and theory of different artistic schools since the Ming and Qing dynasties.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- describe general development of Chinese seals;
- manage general knowledge and appreciation methods of Chinese seals; and

- identify representative master pieces of Chinese seals

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Art Under Imperial Patronage: Chinese Court Painting
courses.description: The course traces the development of Chinese court painting since the Han and Tang dynasties with special reference to the Song and the Qing periods. To evaluate the genre objectively in the historical, artistic and cultural perspectives, extant works will be studied side by side with related literature to reveal the content and style of masterpieces in relation to imperial tastes, political implication, cultural heritage, artistic techniques and Western influences.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Court paintings as the vehicle of political messages.

2. Painting Academy of the Song dynasty.

3. Technical and stylistic features of court painting.

4. The revival of court painting in the Qing.

5. The influence of Western missionaries on Qing court painting.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Modern Challenges: Chinese Art of the Twentieth Century
courses.description: This course traces the development of Chinese art during the twentieth century. Major topics to be covered include new directions of traditionalism and westernization for innovation before 1949, as well as the development of Chinese art on the Mainland and elsewhere since 1949. Special attention will be paid to Chinese artists’ artistic response to political turmoil, cultural changes and Western influences in the new era.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. Know the main political and historical events of the period spanning from the late 19th to the late 20th centuries and how the Chinese visual arts developed under their influence
2. Identify the variety of choices made available to Chinese artists within the profound political and historical changes that took place during the 20th century in Chinese society and culture; these choices were twofold: 1/ promoting and/or expanding Chinese media-based; 2/ exploring new forms of art imported from the West.
3. Recognize some of the most famous artworks produced by Chinese artists in China, Taiwan and the rest of the world during that period.
4. Build informed opinion on the quality and relevance of the arts of the 20th and 21st century in China according to their relation with political and historical events.
5. Develop skills in writing academic essays and speaking in public.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Introduction, the late 19th century**

How new ways of practicing the visual arts came to China

* Art at the end of the imperial period, the end of a political system and its impact on art making
* Art in the treaty ports, how influences from the West began to reshape Chinese art

* *Guohua** **國畫**

How traditional forms of art evolved into new forms

* May Fourth movement; conservative forms of *Guohua* (‘national painting’), the first development of modernity in Chinese culture and their impact on visual art
* Innovative forms of *Guohua,* the reshaping of tradition under the influence of foreign cultures

* *Yanghua** **洋畫** **and Modernism**

How foreign forms of art were introduced and influenced all other forms of art

* Expansion of Western art in the treaty ports; introduction and reinforcement of modernist attitudes
* Western art techniques and hybridity in *Yanghua* (‘foreign painting’)
* How this new cultural context opened the doors to practices whose influence can still be felt nowadays.
* Modern art in China and sculpture

* *Maoist Revolutionary Realism**

How the new ideology produced new forms of art

* Chinese communist art ideology after the foundation of the People’s Republic of China
* Experiments in communal creativity, Marxism and political art making
* Chinese communist traditional painting, the role of tradition in a communist regime
* Chinese communist Western media art, political influences from the communist block
* Propaganda posters, political representations outside the art institutions

* *The 1980s and 1990s, the visual arts evolve away from painting**

How Deng Xiaoping’s Open-Door Policy created the conditions for new experiments

* Return to individual expression in the arts of Mainland China with the first Stars exhibition, the impact of Western liberalisation
* Burgeoning of a developed art market, capitalism and art making
* Beginnings of an art scene linked to globalized contemporary practices.

* *Some Diaspora artists**

How the influence of Chinese art spread around the world

* Reasons for Chinese artists to look for opportunities abroad
* Some artists who left China in the first half of the 20th century
* Some artists who left China after the beginning of the Open-Door policy
* Global influence of some Chinese artists at the beginning of the 21st century

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Western Art II: from Impressionism to the Late 1940s
courses.description: The latter part of the nineteenth century was a time of economic, technological and social change when traditional values were challenged. This revolutionary period marked the beginning of the modern age and the birth of many avant-garde movements. This course aims to examine the various manifestations of these movements and the utopian project they tried to materialize.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- know the general timeframe of the developments of Western art from the late 19th century to the 1960s;
- be able to situate an artwork (sculpture, painting and architecture) within a time period: for example, recognize whether a painting is a Pointillist or a Futurist work; and

- understand the historical background of each period and art movement.

- be able to think and write like an art historian, a curator and an art critic.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Introduction: Academic art

- Before Impressionism, Macchiaioli, Impressionism

- Symbolism and Art Nouveau

- Post-Impressionism

- Expressionism

- The School of Paris and Cubism

- De Stijl and the Bauhaus

- The Dada movement

- Surrealism

- Abstract Expressionism

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Daoist Art
courses.description: This course explores the development of Daoist art, with emphasis on studying artwork in relation to the religious culture and historical context of its production. It concerns how Daoist artwork is linked to Daoist thought, texts and visual culture current in the same period. Students will be introduced to Daoist sculptures, stone carvings, architecture, murals, scripture illustrations, as well as arts that embody Daoist aesthetics and culture, such as landscape paintings, container gardens and garden designs. Through studying archaeological and extant Daoist art and artifacts, together with scholarly research on Daoism and religious art theories, students are expected to acquire in-depth understanding of the development, function and meaning of Daoist art.
courses.course_syllabus:
本課旨在探討中國道教藝術的發展，尤其著重將藝術品置放於宗教文化與歷史脈絡，分析它們與道教思想、經書典籍和視覺文化的關係。課題包括道教造像、石刻、宮觀建築、壁畫、經卷插圖等，亦會涵蓋體現道教文化和審美價值的藝術，例如山水畫和盆景等。本課將通過考察出土和傳世的藝術文物，並結合道教研究及宗教藝術理論，讓學生對道教藝術的源流、功能及宗教涵義有深入認識。
專題包括：
神像的誕生：早期道教造像
神像與觀念：道教石窟
神像與科儀：宮觀壁畫──朝元主題
神像與故事：宮觀壁畫──仙傳及其他
宇宙觀、材質與功能：銅鏡
宇宙觀、圖像與功能：道袍及其他
宇宙觀、文字與功能：符、圖與書法
仙境與人間：山水畫
神仙與人間：神仙畫像

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Creative Workshop for Contemporary Chinese Art
courses.description: This course was designed to bridge Chinese and Western Art through seminars and studio practice. Since the late 1970s, Chinese Art has experienced major breakthroughs and has provided new insights for the development of contemporary art worldwide. The course will therefore re-examine the existing resources of Chinese art and culture and incorporate them using the methodologies of contemporary art in order to create new directions for art practices. Elitist and popular Chinese arts will be reconsidered in order to combine them with a local character and, using the contemporary art methods mainly coming from the West, students will be encouraged to find their own creative directions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- Understand the importance of Contemporary Chinese Art

- Rejuvenate Chinese Art tradition from the a global, contemporary perspective

- Revisit and adopt local, historical Chinese Art resources in art making

- bridge the experiences earned from various studio art courses offered by the Department
courses.course_syllabus:
- Understanding Contemporary Chinese Art

- Possible interpretation on Chineseness and it’s practice in Contemporary Art

- Critique and comparison on Chinese literati art and folk art

- Studio practice-- experiment with traditional material and new concept
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. The CU Forum will also be used if appropriate.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Western Painting II
courses.description: Emphasis is placed on the development of personal imagery and creative expression. Students will be asked to choose a theme or visual idea for exploration. They are not directed to work in any specific style but are encouraged to use the various concepts and techniques to produce expressive paintings. Frequent class discussions and critiques encourage an exchange of ideas.

- understand the materiality and image representation of painting from the perspective of studio art through contemporary art approach; and

- develop individual project on painting.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Printmaking
courses.description: Students in this course learn the principles and techniques of intaglio, relief, planography, and serigraphy. Through learning the techniques on drawing, making and copying of print, students could receive fine arts education from the printmaking course. In addition to teaching various materials and making techniques concerning printmaking, this course also discusses related knowledge on presswork, television, computer and mass media, such as the combination and analysis of colours, craftwork on paper making, the disposal of chemical materials, etc. Regular individual tutorials conducted throughout the course provide students with professional guidance enabling them to master the traditional printmaking techniques and also a new approach to aesthetic value.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After the course, students will be able to

- learn about the off-set printing techniques, wood-cut , stone carving, rubbing, silkscreen in daily and industrial products, and colour reparation

- master the traditional printmaking techniques and the new approach to aesthetic value

- possess the ability of independent creation

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Art in Public Space
courses.description:
Art in pubic space became an important subject for those who wanted to reconcile the conflict between individual artistic ideas and the common norms in public space in 21st century. The presumption that artist cannot contribute significantly to public sector is questionable nowadays—there are many experiments being done to show that artistic intervention can somehow arouse the awareness of hidden power and political structure of the society. As a citizen or an artist, art has a role to play in public space.
Seeing public space as an arena for artistic expression becomes another focus in contemporary art. Gallery, museum which are supposed to be neutral space in showing art is gradually replaced by space with cultural significances; message in art has been put into specific context for holistic examination.
The course will cover various art forms in public space, which include traditionally defined public art, such as sculpture and functional objects in public space. The course will also teach student how to realize an art project through management and negotiation among different stakeholders— the client, the public, the technical consultant and the artist.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students should be able to:

1) understand various forms of public art and their function

2) understand the infra structure and function of different parties involved

3) understand flow and operation of public art project

4) understand communication and contractual matter
courses.course_syllabus:
1) art, context and space

2) politics, esthetics and function in public art

3) various forms in public art

4) operation and flow of public art project

5) technical matter—manufacture, legal matter and engagement of the general public

6) individual and group project
courses.feedback_evaluation: Evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. The CU Forum will also be used if appropriate.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Combined Printmaking
courses.description:
Expressions of ideas and concepts in the printmaking studio are used to be the earlier print technologies like relief, intaglio, screen printing and lithography, while technologies like photographic and digital printing in nowadays, enrich the possibility of creating Artwork. Combined printmaking experiments with contemporary combinations of print formats to produce multi-layered explorations of the image, line, colour, marks and visual expression.
By understanding the characteristics of traditional and modern printing techniques, and the relation between printmaking materials (paper, ink and plate), students are enabled to expand the possibility of image making by transforming the use of printmaking in their own project.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. Creatively apply a selection of printmaking techniques.

2. Gain knowledge and experience of choosing suitable medium and paper in creating print.

3. Identify and transfer knowledge and skills from their existing working mode to apply in a new context.

4. Have confident in expressing their idea thought the printing approach.

5. Be entrenched a standards of professional practice.
courses.course_syllabus:
1/ Basic principle-- characteristics and techniques of intaglio print, relief print, serigraph and lithography.

2/Exploration of combined approaches, with photograph and digital output..

3/Material study-- materials for plate preparation, printing surface, and characteristic of various type of ink.

4/ Layering technique and principle—from concept to practice.

5/ Experimental process in printmaking, which includes: Image transfer techniques, adopting commercial printing techniques in art making and develop unique printmaking approach.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Moving Image Workshop
courses.description: The course is designed to explore the concepts, aesthetics and techniques of moving image in digital format from both academic and studio perspectives. Both technical and aesthetic issues will be addressed. Aesthetic issues encompass concept, relationship of sound and image, video installation and historical context. Technical topics include techniques of cinematography, non-linear editing, scene visualization and other related topics. Non-linear editing and compositing software will be introduced to illustrate the principles and techniques and to produce the projects.
courses.course_syllabus:
Discussion on Contemporary Mainstreams

Workshop and Discussion on Video Time

Workshop and Discussion on Video Space

Workshop and Discussion on Dialogue

Workshop on Location-driven scene establishment

Workshop and Discussion on Multi-channel video

Narrative in Moving Image: Storytelling

Narrative in Moving Image: Documentary

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Figure Sketching
courses.description: The content of this course includes knowledge of human anatomy, sketching of head and statues and sketching of live model. Through a series of exercises, students will acquire a better understanding of depicting human forms. It also enhances students’ powers of expression in figure drawing. The course helps to build the foundation of figure painting which applies for different media.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course is designed for students who are interested to learn figure drawing.

The course covers fundamental knowledge of the human anatomy for artistic purpose, introduction of the drawing of the masters, sketching exercises from life of heads, features, faces and the draped figure.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Calligraphy in Ancient Scripts
courses.description: This course aims to provide a more focused study of ancient Chinese calligraphy before the Qin and Han dynasties. In addition to the training of writing skills, the knowledge of paleography will also be introduced. The course lays a foundation for further pursuit of creation and study. This course can be taken as either an Art History or a Studio Arts elective course but students are required to declare their choice of attribution in their final year of attendance.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course aims to provide a more focused study in ancient Chinese calligraphy before Qin and Han dynasties. In addition to the training of writing skills, the knowledge of paleography will also be introduced in the course. The design of the course is a foundation for further pursuit of creation and study.

It is through the study of Chinese calligraphy in ancient scripts that students can understand the relationship of art and the culture of ancient Chinese society, and can widen their horizon in calligraphy creation, setting a foundation for their study of ancient Chinese art in future.
courses.course_syllabus:
The topics will include:

- introduction to ancient Chinese Calligraphy;
- writing skills in ancient Chinese Calligraphy including oracle-bone inscription, bronze inscription,

stone engravings, bamboo and wooden strips inscription before Qin and Han dynasties; and

- knowledge of paleography.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Gongbi: Chinese Delineative Painting
courses.description: This is an advanced study of Chinese Painting. It focuses on studying the techniques of painting by using fine-line and wash, one of two primary painting techniques in the Chinese tradition. Technique and forms of expression such as ink, light colouring, heavy colouring are included. Students will be encouraged to initiate artistic creation by incorporating different forms of expression. Contents of this course will vary with instructors and students. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- have a thorough understanding of techniques and forms of expression of Chinese delineative painting;
- be able to master the techniques; and

- possess the ability of independent creation
courses.course_syllabus:
The topics will include:

- introduction to materials and tools used in Chinese delineative painting;
- exercise of techniques in brushwork, tone variation and colouring; and

- study of typical style by some important Chinese expressive painters.
