courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Text and Image
courses.description: To explore the relationship between Text and Image, there are three parts in the course’s content: Creative Writing, Image Making and Critic Writing. Creative Writing includes narrative writing, fictional story, life memories, poetry, stream of consciousness… …etc that given a board based understanding of text. Image Making requires to re-think the application of imagery through representation and interpretation of text that be able to re-generate different images relatively. After the transformation from text to image, through the on-looker’s view point to create Critic Writing that using a third party’s perspective to analysis and re-read different kind of possibilities in the process of art making.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. learn different ways of understanding imagery through the experiences of Looking, Telling and Making.

2. understand different point of views and be able to exchange and to discuss the above views with the others.

3. think and apply imagery differently while applying the above experiences onto other art practices.

4. understand the development of imagery from the traditional and the digital / new media method.
courses.course_syllabus:
The topics will include:

1. Lecture on “On Image”

2. “Ways of Telling”

3. “Ways of Seeing”

4. “Ways of Thinking”

5. Re-view & Re-think

6. Lecture on “On Photography”

7. Experimental imaging 1 - capturing

8. Experimental imaging 2 - representation
courses.feedback_evaluation: A clear teaching plan will be provided before the course commences. An evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Chinese Landscape Painting
courses.description: This course includes introduction of different tools and landscape painting skills. The main learning methods are imitation and copy. It aims to allow students get familiar with traditional painting methods and combine with outdoor sketches to finally have a complete understanding in Chinese landscape painting. The students are expected to be able to integrate what he/she has learned, so as to develop a personal painting style finally.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. master various techniques in brushwork, tone variation and coloring in Chinese landscape painting;
2. copy typical styles by some important Chinese landscape painters; and

3. have their own creation in Chinese landscape painting
courses.course_syllabus:
- exercise of various techniques and formats of expression in Chinese landscape painting including Tree method, Mountain and stone method, Cloud and water method ,Landscape decorated method, Composition, Landscape in different time, Color arrangementaint , Paint from life ; and

- study of typical style by some important Chinese landscape painters.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Ceramic Art: Form and Space
courses.description: The course introduces construction skills and knowledge in ceramics through studio practice. Focus will be placed on the creation of form using clay and methods in ceramics. Discussions and critiques will be arranged to enhance the awareness of ceramics in the context of visual culture and contemporary life. Students are encouraged to apply the skills and knowledge learnt in developing their own area of work.
courses.course_syllabus:
The topics will include:

1. Health and safety in ceramic studios

2. Knowledge of material process in clay

3. Hand-building methods and their variations

4. Investigating notions of space through ceramic works

5. Interaction between form and space

6. Perceiving and creating three dimensional forms in contemporary life
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Qualitative feedback from students

2. Reflection of teacher

A clear teaching plan will be provided before the course commences. An evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.

Focus will be placed on exploring and investigating various notions of surface creation in ceramics. Different colouring agents and textures will be applied through traditional and contemporary methods. Through practice and discussion, students are encouraged to explore the role of surfaces on forms in various aspects of contemporary art.

4. Creating dialogue between surface and form

courses.description:
How to engage society through artistic and creative strategies? This course is designed to respond to this question with hands-on experience. This course provides internship placements for students to work with organizations involved in social engagement through creative thinking. Designed in an inter-disciplinary approach, students will not only work closely with artists, but also with social workers, entrepreneurs, designers, therapists, architects, etc. Besides art-administrative works, students are expected to create art projects and assist the organizations in running creative projects during the placement period. Through practical works, students are expected to build capacity to conduct socially-engaged projects in their own in future.
Period of placement usually starts from June to August. All interested students must attend the briefing session conducted in February/March.
This course can be taken as either an Art History or a Studio Arts elective course but students are required to declare their choice of attribution in their final year of attendance.
courses.course_syllabus:
For Undergraduate students year 2 or above, year 3 prioritized. Internship usually starts from June to August. Approximately 150 working hours in 8-10 weeks in total.

Internship Briefing Session in February or March

Matching and interviews with partner institutions in March and April

Internship placement in the agreed period at respective partner institutions

End-of-placement presentation in October or November

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Arts of Medieval China: Three Kingdoms through Five Dynasties
courses.description: This course surveys the art and material culture of medieval China. The medieval or early medieval period spans between the fall of the Han (206 BCE-220 CE) and the establishment of the Song (960-1279). With primary reference to archaeological evidence discovered in the recent six decades, the course considers (1) cities and palaces; (2) tombs and ritual architecture; (3) trans-and intra-regional connections; (4) the rise of new artistic forms, media, and technologies; and (5) the spread of Buddhist visual culture and its impact to Chinese society.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. Gain proficiency in analyzing individual artworks of medieval China.

2. Identify regional variances, trans-regional diffusions, inter-regional commonalities, and historical transformations.

3. Develop skills in writing academic essays and delivering public speech.

4. Forster abilities to enjoy, experience, examine, and create objects of visual culture.

5. Cultivate religious, cultural, and socio-political tolerance.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Tradition and Transformation: Chinese Literati Painting
courses.description: The course traces the development of Chinese literati painting from the Northern Song to the first half of the 20th century. Topics to cover include literati art theories, revivalism, the theory of the Southern and Northern Schools, period styles, regional styles, Ming and Qing schools, reverence for and transformation of antiquity, commercialization of painting, and the modernization of traditional painting.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Song literati’s views of painting.

2. Revivalism in Yuan painting.

3. The Wu School and Zhe School in Ming.

4. The theory of Northern and Southern Schools of Painting.

5. The Orthodox school of painting in early Qing.

6. The Yangzhou eccentrics in mid-Qing.

7. The Shanghai school of painting in late Qing.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Chinese and Western Comparative Aesthetics
courses.description: Relying on famous examples from the Chinese and Western worlds and using several types of sources (literature, philosophy, poetry and the visual arts), this course is divided into two parts. The first part will compare and contrast two radically different conceptions of art. The second part will present the global revolution in thought that has led to today’s developments in the arts created by the Chinese people in Mainland China and abroad.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

- understand the changing historical conditions of the artistic exchange between China and the West and how they have shaped art production in the two worlds;
- understand the analytical history of art theory from the 17th century to the present days in China and the West; and

- better understand the transformations created in art making by these exchanges of ideas and objects.
courses.course_syllabus:
- Moving Epistemes: creative misreadings and fruitful dialogue in the arts of the 18th century.

- Exchanges of superficialities: Chinoiseries in Europe and European Influences in China.

- The Theory of Painting in the 17th and 18th Centuries in Europe.

- The Theory of Painting in the 17th and 18th Centuries in China.

- Comparative Aesthetics.

Who writes and for whom?

Landscape and Space

Brush-Ink

Portrait

History and Death

Allegory and Nude

New types of ‘copy’

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Understanding Theories of Chinese Painting and Calligraphy
courses.description: This course introduces students to the theories of Chinese painting and calligraphy from the Six Dynasties period through the twentieth century. Major theoretical writings will be discussed and analysed to provide students with an understanding of the criteria, views, documentation, principles, and debates of traditional painting and calligraphy. Extant works of painting and calligraphy will be also used as examples to discuss the application of theories.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:

1. describe major theories of Chinese painting and calligraphy;
2. examine the criteria, views, documentation, and principles of traditional Chinese painting and calligraphy; and
3. analyze various debates on theories of painting and calligraphy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Painting and calligraphy theories of the Six Dynasties period
2. Painting and calligraphy theories of the Tang and Five Dynasties periods
3. Painting and calligraphy theories of the Song and Yuan periods
4. Painting and calligraphy theories of the Ming period
5. Painting and calligraphy theories of the Qing period
6. Painting and calligraphy theories of the twentieth century

courses.title: Study of Later Chinese Ceramics
courses.description: This course aims to provide a more focused study in the history of Chinese ceramics from the Yuan to the Qing dynasty. It examines the organization, modes of production and artistic characteristics of the imperial porcelains of Jingdezhen, and discusses the interaction between the ceramic industry of Jingdezhen and other production sites inside and outside China. Major research methodologies and approaches to Chinese ceramics will also be introduced. Students are expected to acquire in-depth understanding of the historical development and technological achievements of later Chinese ceramics through studying historical archives, archaeological reports, ceramic samples and scholarly research. They are also required to undertake independent research on selected topics and present a long essay at the end of the course.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Schools of Model-calligraphy and Stele Studies
courses.description: The course aims at tracing the development of Chinese calligraphy from the migration of the model-calligraphy school to the stele school with special reference to the impact of the Jin-Tang tradition on calligraphers down the ages, factors leading to the rise of stele studies in the Qing dynasty, and the issue of transformation on the basis of the great calligraphic traditions. Topics to be covered include calligraphic theories since the Song dynasty, the prevalence of the Model-calligraphies from the Chunhua Archive and other calligraphic carvings, the preference for copying from ancient masters, the relationship between evidential research and calligraphy, and the works and styles of leading masters. Students of the course are required to conduct thematic research and submit an essay at the end of the term.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Art in Europe and North America After WWII
courses.description: The art practices developed after WWII in Europe and North America have differed so profoundly from those preceding it that many art historians have recognized an irreconcilable break between the two periods. Generally referred to as ‘postmodern art,’ still the most convenient way to separate these practices from the ones called ‘modernist,’ it has offered an extraordinarily wide array of media and strategies. This course will explore some of the many choices made by the artists of these two geographical areas by analyzing their art against their cultural and social backgrounds.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MPhil-PhD Chinese Art or Master of Fine Arts
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to
- understand the developments of European and North American art from the end of WWII to the present days and especially the reasons why the traditional divisions in schools and movements that endured well into the 1960s does not make sense any longer;
- understand the motivations of the most influential artists of that period and how their works were both a product of their time and an engine for the development of other kinds of art practices; and
- and be able to interpret the artworks made by contemporary artists by situating them in the cultural context within which they were created.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: History of Chinese Literati Painting
courses.description: The course aims at tracing the development of literati painting with special reference to literati views on painting held by Su Shi and others since the Song dynasty, the styles and influences of leading painters, and the issue of transformation on the basis of the great painting traditions. Topics to be covered include theories of literati painting, personal styles and regional painting schools, perpetuation and reinvention of the traditions, paintings as commodities, and elitist and popular tastes. Students of the course are required to conduct thematic research and submit an essay at the end of the term.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Comparative Analysis of 17th and 18th Century Painting
courses.description: The comparison of theoretical texts written by Chinese and European painters in the 17th and 18th centuries should clarify the differences – and some similarities – present in two artistic traditions that have developed along very different lines. The first part of the course is dedicated to the study and contextualization of representative texts of the period while, in the second part, a number of the comparative themes thus unveiled will be explored in details using also sources other than the domain of visual arts. Although the emphasis of this course will be on the arts of the 17th and 18th centuries, many of the problems raised during this comparative analysis will lead to an exploration of some issues concerning contemporary art in China and the rest of the world.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Art Theory in Europe and North America From Antiquity to the Present
courses.description: Even a cursory knowledge of Euro-American contemporary art will lead to the realization that one needs to know the writings to understand the visual. If the present situation seems to have made the existence of theory in texts necessary, art theory has however existed for a very long time and in many different forms. To better understand the often very complex thinking that accompanies present-day art practices, it is necessary to understand the history of the thought attached to art. This course specializes in the thinking about art made in Europe and North America from the Antiquity to the present. Three kinds of texts will therefore be used: the writings produced by philosophers about aesthetics and art; the art theory and art criticism written in the public sphere; as well as the writings made by artists on their own practices.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: History of Chinese Court Painting
courses.description: This course traces the development of Chinese court painting from the Qin dynasty through the Qing dynasty. Each class will examine the production and transmission of court painting in light of key concepts in the discourse of Chinese art, which include but are not limited to: stylistic and technical features, political implication, imperial painting academy, genres in art, art patronage, and cross-cultural interactions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Fine Arts, Master of Fine Arts, MPhil-PhD in History of Chinese Art, MPhil-PhD in Chinese Art.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Court paintings as the vehicle of political messages.
2. Painting Academy of the Song dynasty.
3. Technical and stylistic features of court painting.
4. The revival of court painting in the Qing.
5. The influence of Western missionaries on Qing court painting.
courses.feedback_evaluation: A clear teaching plan will be provided before the course commences. An evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Contemporary Art
courses.description: The goal of this course is to explore Western art from approximately 1945 to the mid- 1990s and especially the shift from a modernist to a postmodern culture, as well as how artists have endeavored to address a new era characterized by globalization and consumerism. In parallel, this course will also trace the development of Chinese art during the 20th century. Special attention will be paid to Chinese artists’ response to the political turmoil and cultural changes of the last fifty years.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Fine Arts
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to:
- understand the general timeframe of the developments of Chinese and Western art from the 1960s to the present days;
- understand the social and artistic background of the works of a large number of contemporary artists in order to make them aware of the latest developments in the art field as well as help them find meaning in their own art practices; and
- create an informed opinion on any artwork produced in the postmodern period.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Chinese Art
courses.description: This course aims at providing students with a foundation of Chinese art history which serves as a key source of reference for their artistic creation. Through studying masterpieces of different Chinese artistic traditions, such as painting, calligraphy, religious sculpture, ceramics, lacquer, students will understand the special characteristic and historical development of pre-20th century Chinese art. Special attention will be given to changes in concepts, ways of expression, art techniques and cultural significance of each artistic tradition. Students will be required to conduct thematic research and submit an essay at the end of the term.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Special Topics in Studio Art
courses.description: This course is designed to timely address special issues in visual arts, to provide students with opportunities for in-depth studies with specialists/teachers familiar with current art practices that are normally not covered by our undergraduate curriculum. Topics may include curatorship, art management, cultural policy, public art and/or various studio art workshops or projects.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Fine Arts
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to, particularly in the areas of ‘knowledge, skill, and attitude”:

Knowledge:
- understand how art operates in the society- how different components from art related sectors construct the infra- structure of art; and
- micro ecology: interaction among policy maker, curator, art educator, art consultant, business sector.

Skill:
- keys of writing proposal; project/ studio management;
- communication skill: advocacy for public and private sectors; and
- critical thinking will also be reinforced through discussion of special issues on art related matters.

Attitude:
- ethics for professional practice: freedom of expression/ market force.
courses.course_syllabus:
Local and regional infrastructure of art, Multiple aspects of art as a profession,
Contextualising the practice of contemporary art
courses.feedback_evaluation: Teacher should provide a clear teaching plan before the course commences. Another evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Creative Workshop
courses.description: This course is designed to help students refine their skills and consolidate their knowledge in artistic creation. Besides artistic development on an individual basis, students will be encouraged to carry out independent research in their chosen medium or topic through seminars and critiques. As and when appropriate, the course will be divided into sections to accommodate the different needs of individual students. (Students are required to register for the course for the first three terms.)
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Fine Arts
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to, particularly in the areas of ‘knowledge, skill, and attitude”:

Knowledge:
- acquire an in-depth understanding of various issues of creative process, such as techniques and concepts of contemporary art; and
- understand how art interacted with different disciplines of contemporary world.

Skill:
- increase student’s self-awareness, find their strength, weakness and make ways for improvement, through reflections of the self and the other students.

Attitude:
- seeing art as platform for self, intuitive expression as well as intellectual, academic activities;
- be opened to different art forms , values but need to position oneself through understanding the operation of the art world; and
- develop work ethics.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course will provide supervisions for student’s creative work in different phases. The main topics include:
- general overviews of contemporary art and its connection to art history,
- understanding creative process and development technique,
- pushing boundary of concepts and techniques through varies practices,
- defining individual’s strength and weakness, and
- understanding various forms of presentation in contemporary art.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Graduation Workshop
courses.description:
This course aims at preparing students with necessary skill and tools to understand their own strength and weakness, thus to cope with the challenge of graduation project. Special attention will be given to developing individual beliefs in art, research method and technique, and presentation skill. As and when appropriate, students will also be divided into a few groups and supervised by tutors / specialists of different art practices.

Students are required to submit a written artist statement related to their graduation project and participate in the thesis show (graduation show) as course and graduation requirement.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Fine Arts
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students will be able to, particularly in the areas of ‘knowledge, skill, and attitude”:

Knowledge:
- identify research direction, collect reference and data, and provide guidance on conceptual development; and
- monitor their progress of research and polish their concepts;

Skill:
- understand their strength and weakness, thus to develop necessary skill to cope with their objectives in their graduation work; and
- polish their presentation skills, in order to achieve a better result despite various constrains.

Attitude:
- develop professionalism in art through collaborative work with classmate to realize the graduation exhibition;
- be responsible to serious spectators, develop a clear internal logic of work, and provide sufficient hints for further inquiry of the work; and
- develop work ethics.
courses.course_syllabus:
The graduation workshop is to reinforce student's professional attitude and knowledge to code with the graduation project, which serves as an important evidence to sum up student's achievements/ abilities in art in the programme.
The main topics include:
- review personal artistic development in the past three semesters, and define individual strength.
- review different models and methodogies in making.of contemporary art.
- prepare theoretical text as document to support artistic creation.
- display strategy, art exbibition as venue for re-creation of a studio work.
- individual supervision by external supervisor.

courses.subject: FAAS
courses.title: Chinese Painting and Calligraphy of the Twentieth Century
courses.description: This course traces the development of Chinese Painting and calligraphy in the twentieth century. Major topics to be covered include the influence of foreign styles on Chinese painting and the localization of oil painting in the early twentieth century, the impact of politics on Chinese art making since 1949, as well as the new waves after the reform and opening-up of China, exploring in depth the ways of reform and modernization of Chinese painting and calligraphy in the new era. Through the studies on major Chinese artists and their representative works, the course will provide insights into how the political, economic and social changes, different artistic environments, confrontation and exchange of Chinese and foreign cultures affect the artistic creations and ideas of Chinese painters and calligraphers in the past century.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Fine Arts, Master of Fine Arts, MPhil-PhD in History of Chinese Art, MPhil-PhD in Chinese Art.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing the course, students will be able to:
- have a basic understanding of the trends, styles and evolution of twentieth century Chinese painting and calligraphy.
- know the main historical events of the period spanning from the late 19th to the late 20th centuries and how Chinese painting and calligraphy developed under their influence.
- recognize some of the most famous artworks produced by Chinese painters and calligraphers.
- build informed opinion on the quality and relevance of the arts of the twentieth century in China according to their relation with political and historical events.
- develop skills in writing academic essays and speaking in public.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction: Chinese Painting and Calligraphy in the New Era
• The impact of political and socio-cultural changes on art making during the late Qing period
• How influences from foreign countries began to reshape Chinese art and culture

Reform for Reborn: A Debate between Tradition and Modernity
• The decline of traditionalism and the threat of modern ideas
• Seeking ways to preserve the heritage and revive the tradition in the modern age

Shanghai School: A Mix of Market Taste and Scholarly Interest
• The rise of new art market in the modern Chinese metropolitan Shanghai
• Between old and new: the art circles in Shanghai

Art and Revolution: Lingnan School of Painting
• Revolutionary Spirit in the Guangdong art scene
• The rise of new Chinese painting: Lingnan School of Painting

Innovation with Tradition: Qi Baishi, Huang Binhong, Zhang Daqian and etc.
• Were they progressive traditionalists or conventional reformers?
• How they draw inspirations from the heritage and revitalize the traditional techniques

Academic Style: Xu Beihong and His Peers
• Introduction of western painting to China during the late nineteenth century and early twentieth century
• Localization of oil painting: Xu Beihong and his peers

Modernism in China: From Lin Fengmian to Wu Guanzhong
• Introduction of western modern art to China in the early twentieth century
• The struggle of modernistic painting in China throughout the twentieth century

Implantation of Socialist Realism
•The influence of Soviet Socialist Realism on Chinese art in the New China
•Chinese figure painting in the New China

Painting the New China: Politics and Chinese Painting after 1949
•The new role of Chinese landscape painting
•Representative works created during the 1950s and 1970s

Renaissance of Tradition Chinese Painting
•In Pursuit of personality: Pang Tianshou, Fu Baoshi, Li Keran, Lu Yanshao and etc.
•Introduction of new syllabus for Chinese painting and calligraphy

Contributions of Chinese Artists outside Mainland China in the Second Half of Twentieth Century
• Ink art in Hong Kong and Taiwan
• Leading overseas Chinese artists

Reform and Opening Policy and the Art Movements in the 1980s
•A time of rapid changes in Mainland China and its impact on art and culture development after 1978
•Art Movements in the 1980s; The '85 Ideological Trend

Contemporary Chinese Art at the Turn of the Millennium
•New Art Post-89; The new art experiments in the 1990s
•Global influence on contemporary Chinese art at the turn of the millennium

Chinese Modern Calligraphy as a Reflection of Chinese Modern Culture
•The changing world and the new mode of calligraphy in modern China
•From the Neo-Classicism to the Avant-garde, the diverse development of contemporary Chinese calligraphy
courses.feedback_evaluation: A clear teaching plan will be provided before the course commences. An evaluation exercise will be held at end of the course. An on line discussion platform may be installed if appropriate.
